CSPCED1_rubric_category_0.s:
Points earned:

+1 The video demonstrates the running of the program, including input, program functionality, and output.
Consider only the video when scoring this point.

Do NOT award a point if the following is true:

● The video does not show a demonstration of the program running (screenshots or storyboards are not acceptable and would not be credited).

+1 The program code includes a list, a procedure, a call to the procedure, selection, and iteration.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference (or Program Code if necessary) when scoring this point.

● If the program requirements do not appear in the Personalized Project Reference, consider the full program code file when scoring this point.

● The procedure does not need to have a parameter to earn this point.

● The code segments demonstrating selection and iteration do not need to appear in the same algorithm to earn this point.

● The code segments demonstrating selection and iteration do not need to be contained in a procedure to earn this point.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

● The list is a one-element list.

● The use of the list is irrelevant or not used in the program.

● The use of either the selection or the iteration is trivial (i.e., does not affect the outcome of the program).

+1 The written response identifies an expected user of the program and describes one way the program’s design meets the needs of the identified user.

Consider Written Response 1 and the student’s Program Code when scoring this point.

● The response must relate the program design to the needs of the identified user.

Do NOT award a point if the following is true:

● The description of the design is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

o.d: Total number of points earned is equal to 0.
Total number of points earned is equal to 1.
Total number of points earned is equal to 2.
Total number of points earned is equal to 3.

CSPCED2_rubric_category_0.s:
Points earned:

+1 Written response 2(a) identifies the number of times the body of the iteration statement will execute. In addition, written response 2(a) describes a condition or error that would cause an infinite loop or, if no such condition or error exists, explains how the loop could be modified to cause an infinite loop.
Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(a) when scoring this point.

● If multiple iteration statements are included in the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first iteration statement to determine whether the point is earned.

● The iteration statement does not need to be contained in a procedure to earn this point.

Do NOT award a point if the following is true:

● The identified number of times the body of the iteration statement will execute does not match the code.

+1 Written response 2(b) describes a change to the procedure that will result in a run-time error and explains why the change will result in a run-time error.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(b) when scoring this point.

● If multiple procedures are included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first procedure to determine whether the point is earned.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

● A procedure is not identified in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

● The response does not apply to the procedure in in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

● The response describes expected behavior that is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

+1 Written response 2(c) explains in detailed steps an algorithm that uses isEqual to count the number of elements in the list that are equal to a certain value.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(c) when scoring this point.

● If multiple lists are included in the List section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first list to determine whether the point is earned.

● The algorithm can be described in code, pseudocode, as a sequence of steps in English, or as a paragraph in English.

● The algorithm must describe iterating over all elements of the list, calling isEqual on each list element and maintaining a count of the number of list elements equal to a certain value.

● The algorithm must correctly determine the number of elements that are equal to a certain value. Some ways this can be determined is by storing the value in a variable, returning it, or displaying it to the user.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

● A list is not identified in the List section of the Personalized Project Reference.

● The description of the algorithm is not detailed enough for someone else to write the code.

o.d: Total number of points earned is equal to 0.
Total number of points earned is equal to 1.
Total number of points earned is equal to 2.
Total number of points earned is equal to 3.

NOTE: On the AP Exam, to earn a point for a rubric row, responses will need to meet all criteria for that row.

Points earned:

+1 [Skill 3.B] The response includes a code segment that contains a student-developed procedure that implements an algorithm used in the program.

Do NOT award a point if:

● the procedure is a built-in or existing procedure or language structure, such as an event handler or main method, where the student only implements the body of the procedure rather than defining the name, return type (if applicable) and parameters

+1 [Skill 3.B] The response includes a code segment that shows a call to the procedure.

+1 [Skill 3.B] The response describes in general what the identified procedure does and how it contributes to the overall functionality of the program.

Do NOT award a point if:

● the code segment consisting of the procedure is not included in the written responses section.

● the procedure is a built-in or existing procedure or language structure, such as an event handler or main method, where the student only implements the body of the procedure rather than defining the name, return type (if applicable) and parameters.

● the written response describes what the procedure does independently without relating it to the overall function of the program.

VR786896_rubric_category_0.s:
Points earned:

+1 The video demonstrates the running of the program, including input, program functionality, and output.
Consider only the video when scoring this point.

Do NOT award a point if the following is true:

  • The video does not show a demonstration of the program running (screenshots or storyboards are not acceptable and would not be credited).

+1 The program code includes a list, a procedure, a call to the procedure, selection, and iteration.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference (or Program Code if necessary) when scoring this point.

  • If the program requirements do not appear in the Personalized Project Reference, consider the full program code file when scoring this point.

  • The procedure does not need to have a parameter to earn this point.

  • The code segments demonstrating selection and iteration do not need to appear in the same algorithm to earn this point.

  • The code segments demonstrating selection and iteration do not need to be contained in a procedure to earn this point.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • The list is a one-element list.

  • The use of the list is irrelevant or not used in the program.

  • The use of either the selection or the iteration is trivial (i.e., does not affect the outcome of the program).

+1 The written response describes a piece of documentation that would be appropriate to include in the program and describes the intended purpose of the documentation by identifying who would use it and what they would do with it.

Consider the Video (or Program Code if necessary) and Written Response 1 when scoring this point.

  • The response must relate the documentation to the identified user(s).

  • Appropriate uses of documentation include acknowledgment of code segments written by someone else or descriptions of what a code segment does or how it works.

  • Responses can be a general description of the documentation or a specific comment that would be included in the program code.

Do NOT award a point if the following is true:

  • The description of the design is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

o.d: Total number of points earned is equal to 0.
Total number of points earned is equal to 1.
Total number of points earned is equal to 2.
Total number of points earned is equal to 3.

VR786898_rubric_category_0.s:
Points earned:

+1 Written response 2(a) describes the condition(s) that will cause the body of the iteration statement to execute at least once.
Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(a) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple iteration statements are included in the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first iteration statement to determine whether the point is earned.

  • The iteration statement does not need to be contained in a procedure to earn this point.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • No iteration statement appears in the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The identified condition does not cause the body of the iteration statement to execute at least once.

  • The explanation does not match the code in the first iteration statement.

+1 Written response 2(b) includes a procedure call with specific arguments and describes the functionality that is related to the provided procedure call.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(b) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple procedures are included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first procedure to determine whether the point is earned.

  • The parameter(s) used in the procedure must be explicit. Explicit parameters are defined in the header of the procedure.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A procedure is not identified in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response does not apply to the procedure in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response describes expected functionality that is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

+1 Written response 2(c) explains how the program would need to be adjusted if the list was not included in the program code.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(c) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple lists are included in the List section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first list to determine whether the point is earned.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A list is not identified in the List section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The explanation provided is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with how the program would need to be adjusted if the list was not included.

  • If the program requirements do not appear in the Personalized Project Reference, consider the full program code file when scoring this point.

  • The procedure does not need to have a parameter to earn this point.

  • The code segments demonstrating selection and iteration do not need to appear in the same algorithm to earn this point.

  • The code segments demonstrating selection and iteration do not need to be contained in a procedure to earn this point.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • The list is a one-element list.

  • The use of the list is irrelevant or not used in the program.

  • The use of either the selection or the iteration is trivial (i.e., does not affect the outcome of the program).

VR786901_rubric_category_0.s:
Points earned:

+1 Written response 2(a) identifies a Boolean expression equivalent to the one included in the first conditional statement in the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(a) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple conditional statements are included in the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first conditional statement to determine whether the point is earned.

  • The conditional statement does not need to be contained in a procedure to earn this point.

Do NOT award a point if the following is true:

  • The identified Boolean expression does not evaluate to the same value as the expression in the conditional statement for all possible values of the included variables.

+1 Written response 2(b) identifies a strategy for testing the correctness of the procedure and describes how the strategy could be used to test the procedure.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(b) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple procedures are included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first procedure to determine whether the point is earned.

  • Some strategies for testing include (but are not limited to) hand tracing, use of visualizations, use of debuggers, adding extra output statements, and commenting out lines of code.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A procedure is not identified in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response does not apply to the procedure in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response identifies a strategy that is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

+1 Written response 2(c) identifies the subproblem being solved or task being accomplished by the procedure and explains how the procedure is used to accomplish the overall functionality of the program.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(c) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple procedures are included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first procedure to determine whether the point is earned.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A procedure is not identified in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response does not apply to the procedure in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response includes an explanation that is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

VR786909_rubric_category_0.s:
Points earned:

+1 Written response 2(a) explains in detailed steps how the code segment in part (ii) of the List section of the Personalized Project Reference works.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(a) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple lists are included in the List section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first list to determine whether the point is earned.

  • The explanation can be described in pseudocode, as a sequence of steps in English, or as a paragraph in English.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A list is not identified in the List section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The description of the code segment is not detailed enough for someone else to write the code.

+1 Written response 2(b):

  • describes where output statements can be inserted in the procedure to test whether a block of code is executed or not.

    OR

  • explains why it is not possible for different arguments to cause different segments of code to execute.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(b) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple procedures are included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first procedure to determine whether the point is earned.

  • If code lines are clearly numbered, responses can reference line numbers when responding to this question. If no numbering is included, responses should identify lines of code by copying the lines into the response.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A procedure is not identified in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response does not apply to the procedure in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response describes output statements that are implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.

+1 Written response 2(c) explains how the program could be written differently if one of the parameters was removed from the procedure.

Consider the Personalized Project Reference and Written Response 2(c) when scoring this point.

  • If multiple procedures are included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference, use the first procedure to determine whether the point is earned.

  • The parameter identified to be removed must be explicit. Explicit parameters are defined in the header of the procedure.

Do NOT award a point if any one or more of the following is true:

  • A procedure is not identified in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The first procedure included in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference does not contain an explicit parameter.

  • The response does not apply to the procedure in part (i) of the Procedure section of the Personalized Project Reference.

  • The response includes an explanation that is implausible, inaccurate, or inconsistent with the program.
